pr_title: Implement containsAny and containsNone on primitive iterables. Closes #1007.

timeline.message:
Implement containsAny and containsNone on primitive iterables. Closes #1007.

Signed-off-by: Rinat Gatyatullin <rinattalgatovich.gatyatullin@bnymellon.com>

timeline.bodyText: change this to an indexed for loop
timeline.author: nikhilnanivadekar

replies.bodyText: why? Arrays are the only types where the non-indexed for-loop has no overhead.
replies.author: mohrezaei

replies.bodyText: I was thinking to keep it consistent in the entire codebase. Throughout we tend to prefer indexed for loops
replies.author: nikhilnanivadekar

replies.bodyText: Changed to an indexed for loop.
replies.author: rinatigati

timeline.message:
Fix bug with noneSatisfy for ImmutableBooleanEmptySet.

Signed-off-by: Rinat Gatyatullin <rinattalgatovich.gatyatullin@bnymellon.com>

Fix bug with noneSatisfy for ImmutableBooleanEmptySet.

Signed-off-by: Rinat Gatyatullin <rinattalgatovich.gatyatullin@bnymellon.com>

timeline.author: mohrezaei
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -127,6 +127,140 @@ public interface <name>Iterable extends PrimitiveIterable
         }
     }
 
+    /**
+     * Returns true if any of the values specified in the source array are contained
+     * in the <name>Iterable, and false if they are not.
+     *
+     * @since 11.0
+     */
+    default boolean containsAny(<type>... source)
+    {
+        if (this.size() \<= 32 || source.length \<= 32)

replies.bodyText: Good point! I simplified all 4 methods and updated the PR.
replies.author: rinatigati

timeline.message:
Fix bug with noneSatisfy for ImmutableBooleanEmptySet.

Signed-off-by: Rinat Gatyatullin <rinattalgatovich.gatyatullin@bnymellon.com>

timeline.bodyText: at this point inside is guaranteed to be the smaller of the two. Therefore, inside.size() > 32 implies outside.size() > 32. We can drop outside.size() > 32. Same for noneSatisfy
timeline.author: mohrezaei

timeline.message:
Fix bug with noneSatisfy for ImmutableBooleanEmptySet.

Signed-off-by: Rinat Gatyatullin <rinattalgatovich.gatyatullin@bnymellon.com>

timeline.author: mohrezaei

replies.bodyText: Hi @rinatigati, any questions or updates on the suggestion from @mohrezaei above?
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText:
@donraab Nope! Sounded good to me. I updated the PR with @mohrezaei's suggestions.
Looks like there were artifact transfer failures/connection problems with a couple of the checks. Will have to re-run those somehow.
replies.author: rinatigati

timeline.message:
Fix bug with noneSatisfy for ImmutableBooleanEmptySet.

Signed-off-by: Rinat Gatyatullin <rinattalgatovich.gatyatullin@bnymellon.com>

timeline.author: mohrezaei

replies.bodyText:
No worries!
Added acceptance tests for containsAny and containsNone with source.length == 32 and this.size() == 1M. Runtime of those on my Macbook is ~50ms with the current implementation.
Tried changing it to what you provided above but containsAny can't take the output of Arrays.asList() and gives me the following error:
error: no suitable method found for containsAny(List<int[]>)
    method IntIterable.containsAny(int...) is not applicable
      (varargs mismatch; no instance(s) of type variable(s) T exist so that List<T> conforms to int)
    method IntIterable.containsAny(IntIterable) is not applicable
      (argument mismatch; no instance(s) of type variable(s) T exist so that List<T> conforms to IntIterable)
  where T is a type-variable:
    T extends Object declared in method <T>asList(T...)

I also can't use either IntSets or IntLists to make a primitive iterable since these are default methods in org.eclipse.collections.api and those are in org.eclipse.collections.impl. 🤷 Not sure where to go from here but I did push the acceptance tests I added.
replies.author: rinatigati

replies.bodyText:
You can’t use the factories in API because of the packages and primitives are not onboarded to classloaders like the object side. You cannot use Arrays.asList() as you need to remain in primitive collections.
An option which you have is to move this optimization down to implementations where you can use the factories and keep the unoptimized default method in the interface.
replies.author: nikhilnanivadekar

replies.bodyText: before we go down that route, let's figure out the performance impact. Run the proposed new code and compare the timing with the older one.
replies.author: mohrezaei

replies.bodyText:
The older (current) code completes containsAny and containsNone with source of size 32 and the Iterable of size 1M in 50-60ms on my macbook.
To try out the proposed new code I overrode containsAny(int... source) and containsNone(int.. source) on AbstractIntIterable with it. I did change Arrays.asList(source) to IntLists.mutable.with(source) since I couldn't use Arrays.asList there.
With the same acceptance test (size.length == 32 and this.size() == 1M), the proposed new code completes containsAny and containsNone in 100-120ms on my macbook. It actually seems slower.
replies.author: rinatigati
